I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has been requested by the Association of Southeast 
Asian Nations (ASEAN) to provide technical assistance (TA) supporting the development and 
integration of regional capital markets. ASEAN’s request focuses on the ASEAN economic 
community (AEC) blueprint,1 specifically in relation to its target of freer capital flows that falls 
under the objective of creating a single production base. With a view to accelerating capital 
markets integration while recognizing the individual circumstances of each member country, an 
implementation plan should be finalized by the regulators of capital markets, specifically the 
ASEAN Capital Markets Forum (ACMF), to take measured steps toward adopting harmonized 
capital markets standards, achieving mutual recognition frameworks, and developing exchange 
alliances. This TA2 will build on these organizations’ recent initiatives and on prior ADB support 
to them. 3 Consultations with the relevant countries and regional bodies noted above were 
undertaken in October 2007 and May 2008, the last of which was with the ACMF at the 
Securities Commission, Malaysia on 8 May 2008. The design and monitoring framework is in 
Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Over  the  past  decade,  Southeast  Asian  countries  have  made  substantial  progress  in 
strengthening financial markets while advancing regional cooperation and integration. Financial 
markets have become deeper and more diversified, there is a wider range of products and 
intermediaries, and much has been done to strengthen financial infrastructure. On average, total 
financial assets in the banking sector, equity market capitalization, and bonds outstanding, 
respectively, as percentages of GDP among the ASEAN 5 countries (Indonesia, Malaysia, the 
Philippines, Singapore, and Thailand) improved from 78.0%, 53.8%, and 22.6% in 1997 to 
112.3%, 99.6%, and 50.7% in 2005. In addition, regulatory and prudential supervision has been 
strengthened, as has corporate governance, and there is greater recognition of risk issues with 
a  corresponding  focus  on  internal  controls,  risk  management  systems,  and  consolidated 
supervision.  
 
3.   ADB’s Southeast Asia regional department has helped countries in the region progress 
toward more robust and diversified financial markets at both the national and regional levels. At 
country level, ADB has initiated program loans, projects, and TA. A key objective in country-
level operations is to accelerate convergence to international standards for transparency and 
disclosure; regulatory principles and practices; trading, clearing and settlement systems; risk 
management; and governance. In addition, ADB has implemented a number of regional TA 
(RETA) projects to complement individual countries’ financial sector initiatives. Studies under 
the RETA analyzed broad trends in both western capital markets and those in Southeast Asia. 
They identified the need to develop a strategy promoting greater integration of the latter markets 
while enabling those markets to compete more effectively and to benefit from globalization and 
technological developments.  
 
4.  Capital Market Integration. These studies highlight the considerable differences in the 
levels of national capital markets’ development, including the extents to which they observe 
                                                 
1  The blueprint, adopted by ASEAN member countries in November 2007, aims to transform ASEAN into a single 
market  and  a  more  competitive  economic  region.  It  seeks  more  equitable  economic  development  and  full 
integration into the global economy. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 18 April 2008. 
3  ADB. 2005. Technical Assistance for Supporting Enhanced Cooperation among Southeast Asian Equity Markets. 
Manila (TA 6298-REG, for $500,000).

2 
international regulatory and governance standards. All countries have made significant progress 
in improving the depth, trading volume, and openness of their markets. The share of foreign 
investors in their national equity markets has grown rapidly, but the number of their listings and 
their degrees of openness within ASEAN remain low. The markets generally lag behind more 
developed regions in terms of depth and quality. The markets remain relatively illiquid and have 
high trading costs because of their subscale trading volumes. With stiffer competition among 
world stock exchanges, the emergence of alternative trading networks, and rapid growth in 
trading volumes internationally, Southeast Asian countries agree that regional integration is 
needed  to  expand  their  market  capacity  and  scale  so  that  they  can  compete  globally. 
Cooperation and integration thus feature as key objectives within ASEAN. Countries expect this 
will require a continued focus on strengthening and liberalizing domestic capital markets in order 
to build capacity for domestic players to compete effectively and to manage risks.  
 
5.  In this context, RETA 6298 initiated a consultative process in ASEAN to develop a strategic 
framework for enhanced cooperation in capital markets. It led to consensus on key elements of 
a strategy, including steps to support an exchange alliance framework (cross-ownership and 
trading linkages), and on the need to clarify implementation issues and develop related action 
plans for moving forward. To achieve interlinked capital markets, ADB’s studies highlighted, 
among other factors, the key importance of close coordination between national strategies for 
capital market development and cooperation between regulatory authorities to bring about a 
mutual recognition framework supported by global standards, such as those of the International 
Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO), and harmonization of national legal and 
regulatory frameworks. This would serve to address the key impediment to interlinked securities 
markets that consists in differences between legal and regulatory frameworks and in regulatory 
oversight  of  market  practices.  A sustained  effort  toward  deeper  regulatory  collaboration  in 
ASEAN through the ACMF was thus identified as a necessary step toward the objective of 
capital  market  integration.  In  parallel,  the  ADB-financed  undertaking  led  to  establishing  a 
strategy working group by the ASEAN stock exchanges in 2007 with a view to achieving single 
access to one another’s exchanges as the first step toward building an exchange alliance and 
greater market linkages between them.  
 
6.   Harmonization  and  Mutual  Recognition.  Further  progress  on  achieving  interlinked 
securities markets is critically reliant on measures undertaken by regulators to ease current 
regulatory and other impediments to cross-border financial transactions. In particular, greater 
clarity and progress in harmonizing and mutually recognizing regulations, practices, products, 
and intermediaries are needed in order to facilitate regional integration. Priority areas for mutual 
recognition and/or harmonization include capital raising through initial public offerings, licensing 
of  collective  investment  schemes,  solvency  of  brokers,  and  qualification  of  investment 
professionals. Core regulations and laws for prudential and investor protection purposes in 
these areas must be harmonized to some degree in parallel with greater mutual recognition 
where harmonization appears difficult. Such measures need to be designed with a view to 
enhancing the ability of intermediaries to raise capital—and for investors to invest—anywhere in 
the region, and ideally from a single access point.  
 
7.  These objectives are proposed to be realized in the context of the AEC blueprint for 2015 
through its focus on integrating capital markets by means of freer capital flows. The proposal 
was endorsed by the ASEAN finance ministers at their April 2008 meeting in Hanoi. Thus, a 
coherent implementation plan is to be drawn up for each of the blueprint’s components. The 
work of the ASEAN exchanges must also be facilitated to overcome existing regulatory and 
other impediments to cross-border transactions, among other issues. In parallel, strengthened 
observance of IOSCO principles is viewed as a key national objective for each country in order

3 
to develop deeper and more resilient capital markets. Progress toward achieving common 
standards, such as the IOSCO principles, facilitates regional harmonization of regulatory and 
legal frameworks for securities markets and represents an important component of regulatory 
coordination that is sought in ASEAN. ADB has provided support to help developing member 
countries  meet  IOSCO  standards  for  sharing  of  information,  and  this  work  needs  to  be 
sustained and expanded to strengthen mutual recognition frameworks in Southeast Asia. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The impact of the proposed TA is freer flow of capital in Southeast Asia. The outcome of 
the project will be greater harmonization and broader mutual recognition in Southeast Asian 
capital markets. The TA has been coordinated with, and will complement, the work undertaken 
by the Office of Regional Economic Integration in Southeast Asia.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.   ASEAN Capital Markets. The TA will assist ACMF to develop an implementation plan 
for capital market integration that will enhance the abilities (i) for a company in one country to 
raise  financing  in  another  through  wholesale  and/or  retail  markets  in  debt  and/or  equity 
securities, (ii) for intermediaries in one country to offer services in another country, and (iii) for 
brokers and investors to access ASEAN markets from a single entry point of their choice. To 
provide advice for this purpose, ACMF will form a group of experts drawn from well-known 
national figures in ASEAN countries knowledgeable in capital market issues. 
 
10.  Based on earlier work and on additional surveys, workshops, and research, the TA will 
support the ACMF in developing an implementation plan for an integrated capital market and to 
achieve the AEC blueprint for 2015. The plan will outline a cohesive strategy, identify specific 
initiatives,  and  establish  clear  milestones.  It  will  encompass  (i)  greater  harmonization  of 
standards (offerings, disclosure, etc), (ii) mutual recognition of professional qualifications, (iii) 
greater  flexibility  in  language  and  legal  requirements  for  securities  markets,  (iv)  enhanced 
withholding tax structure, (v) facilitation of market linkages (including exchange alliances) as 
indicated by the AEC blueprint for 2015, and (vi) a broader mutual recognition framework 
including collective investment schemes. The TA will also support the strategy working group to 
implement  an  exchange  alliance  framework  that  will  assist  in  progressively  analyzing  and 
formulating solutions to achieving closer linkages in trading, marketing, settlement, clearing, and 
depository systems that underpin equity markets. In addition, the TA will assist Southeast Asian 
securities  regulators  to  meet  obligations  under  the  IOSCO  Multilateral  Memorandum  of 
Understanding Concerning Consultation and Cooperation and the Exchange of Information 
(MMOU) 4 benchmarks, on the IOSCO self-assessment exercise, and in implementing mutual 
regulatory initiatives that include those of IOSCO’s Asia Pacific Regional Committee and of the 
Capital Market Development Forum (ASEAN).  
 
                                                 
4 IOSCO adopted the MMOU in May 2002. Regulators who are able to share public and nonpublic information are 
eligible to sign Appendix A of the MMOU, while regulators facing impediments to information sharing are eligible to 
sign Appendix B. For Appendix B signatories, IOSCO will monitor progress in addressing these impediments.

4 
C.  Cost and Financing 
11.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $650,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on 
a  grant  basis  by  the  Regional  Cooperation  and  Integration  Fund  under  the  Regional 
Cooperation and Integration Financing Partnership Facility. It will cover the costs of engaging 
consultants and preparing reports. The TA will also finance regional workshops and seminars to 
disseminate its findings, gather views on the feasibility of its proposals, and facilitate agreement 
on new initiatives and actions. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
No activity will be financed in any member country under this RETA unless and until a letter of 
no objection, if needed, in respect of such activity has been received from the government of 
such member country. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
12.  ADB will be the Executing Agency for the TA. The TA will involve workshops, surveys, 
and reports to support the ACMF in its deliberations. The TA will be implemented over 18 
months, from August 2008 to January 2010.  
 
13.  ADB  will  recruit  a  firm  to  provide  international  and  national  consulting  services. 
Consulting services will consist of 5 international consultants (15 person-months) and 4 national 
consultants (10 person-months). The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with its 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). Single-source 
selection  of  consultants  is  recommended  using  biodata  technical  proposal,  taking  into 
consideration especially (i) the continuation of work in relation to RETA 6298 carried out by the 
consulting firm, and (ii) the highly specialized nature of many of the assignments. The outline 
terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. Equipment and office supplies to be 
financed by the TA will be procured by the consultants or ADB in accordance with ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time) or other procedures acceptable 
to ADB. Upon completion of the TA, the procured equipment will become the property of ADB. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
14.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of the technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $650,000 to be financed on 
a  grant  basis  by  the  Regional  Cooperation  and  Integration  Fund  under  the  Regional 
Cooperation and Integration Financing Partnership Facility for Strengthening Southeast Asian 
Financial Markets, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  ADB will recruit a firm or institution to provide international and national consulting 
services. Consulting services will consist of 5 international consultants (15 person-months) and 
4 national consultants (10 person-months).  
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
2.  Drawing  on  earlier  work  and  on  additional  surveys,  workshops,  and  research,  the 
consultants  will  support  the  ASEAN  Capital  Markets  Forum  (ACMF)  in  identifying  the  key 
regulatory  areas  requiring  strengthening  and  harmonization  and  in  formulating  an 
implementation  framework  for  mutual  recognition  to  advance  the  interlinking  of  securities 
markets under the Asian Economic Community (AEC) objectives, including those related to the 
emerging  exchange  alliance  framework.  The  implementation  plan  will  be  shaped  by  the 
following guiding principles: (i) greater harmonization of standards relating to issuers, investors, 
and capital market intermediaries; (ii) mutual recognition of products and capital market services 
to  facilitate  the  ability  for  companies  in  one  country  to  raise  financing  in  another  through 
wholesale and/or retail markets using debt and/or equity securities, the ability for intermediaries 
in one country to offer products and services in another country, and the ability for brokers and 
investors to access Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) markets from a single 
point of entry; (iii) greater harmonization in the regional equity market operating environment, 
including standardization of trading hours, listing requirements, and other rules; (iv) greater 
flexibility in language and legal requirements for securities markets; (v) enhanced withholding 
tax structure; (vi) facilitation of market linkages through, for example, collaboration and linkages 
between  exchanges,  trading  platforms,  clearing  and  settlement  facilities,  and  back  office 
functions; (vii) creation of products and services to promote ASEAN as an asset class and an 
attractive  investment  destination;  and  (viii)  promoting  enabling  conditions  to  facilitate 
intraregional flows in the region and recycle regional surplus savings. In particular, consultants 
will  (i)  provide  assistance  to  ASEAN  Exchange  CEOs  on  exchange  alliances,  (ii)  identify 
portfolio and capital account restrictions that need to be phased out to support exchange 
alliances and market linkages, (iii) propose a sequencing of reforms in these areas, and (iv) 
assist Southeast Asian securities regulators in complying with the International Organization of 
Securities  Commissions  (IOSCO)  Multilateral  Memorandum  of  Understanding  (MMOU)  on 
information  exchange.  The  tasks  of  the  consultants  will  include  but  not  be  limited  to  the 
following: 
 
1.   Regional capital market development expert and project guide (3 person- 
months) (team leader) 
 
3.  The team leader will be responsible for the overall organization and management of the 
technical assistance (TA) and timely delivery of outputs. The team leader is expected to have 
significant expertise in developing capital markets in both developed and emerging markets, 
including  knowledge  of  European  Union  regulations  and  experience  in  promoting  linkages 
among capital markets. Experience in the Southeast Asia region is preferable. The team leader 
will work closely with the ACMF and a group of experts to be drawn by the ACMF from 
well-known  national  figures  in  ASEAN  countries  knowledgeable  in  capital  market  issues, 
ASEAN  committees  and  task  forces,  IOSCO’s  Asia  Pacific  Regional  Committee,  ASEAN 
Exchange  CEOs  and  its  working  groups,  capital  market  regulators  in  the  six  countries 
participating in the project, and major market players. The team leader will undertake the 
following tasks:

10  Appendix 3 
(i)  Support the ACMF in developing an implementation plan for an integrated capital 
market to achieve the AEC blueprint for 2015, which will encompass the guiding 
principles noted above. 
(ii)  Identify key areas where harmonization of capital market regulations is needed in 
the ASEAN countries and assist in developing a mutual recognition framework 
for securities markets regulators. 
(iii)  Liaise among the ACMF, ASEAN Secretariat, IOSCO, participating countries, 
and  ADB.  Bring  to  the  attention of  the  agencies concerned  and  of  ADB  all 
matters needing to be addressed for facilitating TA implementation.  
(iv)  Provide guidance for timely delivery of quality outputs consistent with the terms 
of  reference.  Monitor  progress  and  fine-tune  the  TA  as  necessary,  paying 
particular attention to proper sequencing of the various TA elements. Ensure that 
the work is distributed among the various components of the TA.  
(v)  Oversee implementation of TA deliverables, including to prepare an inception 
report with a work plan for each consultant and a timeframe for deliverables and 
related workshops, plus the mid-term, draft final, and final reports. Coordinate 
work of other experts. 
(vi)  Guide  and  participate  in  country  visits,  conferences,  and  working  group 
meetings. 
(vii)  Help identify new initiatives to promote enhanced cooperation in regional equity 
markets. 
 
2.  Regional equity market micro structure expert (3 person-months)  
 
4.   The consultant will have significant expertise in (i) international stock exchange alliances 
and their structures and operational procedures; (ii) securities market operations, including 
trading,  clearance,  and  settlement  systems;  (iii)  assessment  of  technology  (software  and 
hardware) needed to initiate linkup; (iv) operational procedures of stock exchanges, listing 
procedures,  and  market  dealings;  and  (v)  designing  and  conducting  training  programs  on 
securities and stock market operations. The expert will have experience in both developed and 
developing countries and will undertake these tasks: 
(i)  Define possible options for exchange alliances. 
(ii)  Work closely with the technical working group established by ASEAN Exchange 
CEOs to help establish and thresh out matters regarding technical requirements, 
overall design, investment needs, costs, revenues, and other implications of the 
exchange alliance model. 
(iii)  Support implementation of an exchange alliance model and assist in progressively 
analyzing  and  formulating  solutions  for  achieving  closer  linkages  in  trading, 
marketing, settlement, clearing, and depository systems that underpin equity markets.  
(iv)  Participate in meetings and conferences of the technical working group and work 
with the project guide and project coordinator in defining implementation plans 
and new initiatives to promote exchange and capital market cooperation. 
(v)  Assist in identifying and promoting initial groups of alliance partners to begin 
constructing the exchange linkages.  
(vi)  Prepare a report on the ongoing work on exchange alliances and other aspects 
mentioned above, and present this in various conferences to report progress on 
exchange alliances and regional integration.

Appendix 3  11 
3.  Capital account and exchange arrangements expert (3 person-months) 
 
5.   The consultant will be an economist with in-depth experience in monetary policy, cross-
border  investments,  and  liberalization  of  capital  market  restrictions,  plus  relevant  work 
experience  in  developing  and  developed  economies.  Experience  in  the  six  participating 
countries is preferable. The expert will undertake these tasks: 
(i)  Identify exchange and portfolio restrictions that impede cross-border investments 
and capital raising in the ASEAN region. 
(ii)  Assist central banks and ministries of finance to examine capital account and 
exchange control impediments to exchange linkage by way of monitoring and 
analyzing implications of larger transactions volumes on stock exchanges in their 
respective jurisdictions. 
(iii)  Propose a sequencing of reforms to liberalize the capital account restrictions, if 
any, to support the emerging exchange alliance framework and eventually move 
toward greater regional and global integration. 
(iv)  Propose a broad framework and principles for mutual recognition of products, 
services,  and  institutions,  and  propose  a  sequencing  framework  for  mutual 
recognition to support the emerging exchange alliance framework. 
(v)  Prepare a report on the above and present it in various conferences to review 
and report on progress in regional integration and exchange alliances. 
  
4.  Capital market regulations expert (3 person-months) 
 
6.  The expert will have significant experience in capital market regulation in developed and 
developing markets and working knowledge of implementing IOSCO best practice principles 
and  objectives  of  securities  regulation,  including  benchmarks  under  the  IOSCO  MMOU. 
Experience in the six participating countries is preferable. The expert will undertake these tasks: 
(i)  Support  the  ACMF  in  developing  an  implementation  plan  for  capital  market 
integration that will enhance the abilities (a) for companies in one country to raise 
financing in another through wholesale and/or retail markets in debt and/or equity 
securities,  (b)  for  intermediaries  in  one  country  to  offer  services  in  another 
country, and (c) for brokers and investors to access ASEAN markets from a 
single entry point of their choosing.  
(ii)  Identify key areas where harmonization of capital market regulations is needed in 
the ASEAN countries, assist in developing a mutual recognition framework for 
securities  markets  regulators,  and  examine  and  support  prospects  for  an 
exchange alliance.  
(iii)  Identify the major gaps in capital markets regulation (including exchanges’ self-
regulatory frameworks) related to IOSCO objectives and principles.  
(iv)  Assist  Southeast  Asian  securities  regulators  in  meeting  the  IOSCO  MMOU 
benchmarks,  in  the  IOSCO  self-assessment  exercise,  and  in  implementing 
mutual regulation initiatives (including those of IOSCO’s Asia Pacific Regional 
Committee and the Capital Market Development Forum [ASEAN]). 
(v)  Help develop a mutual recognition framework, in collaboration with the capital 
account and exchange arrangements expert, and formulate an implementation 
plan for regulatory convergence.  
(vi)  Prepare a report on the above and present it at the various conferences to review 
and report on progress in regional integration and exchange alliances.

12  Appendix 3 
5.  Capital market expert and project coordinator (3 person-months) 
 
7.  The project coordinator will have significant experience in capital markets in developed 
and developing markets and working knowledge of implementing IOSCO best practices of 
securities regulation. The expert should have experience in managing complex capital market 
projects involving several countries. The expert will undertake these tasks: 
(i)  Work  with  the  team  leader  to  oversee  implementation  of  TA  deliverables, 
including to prepare an inception report with a work plan for each consultant and 
a timeframe for deliverables and related workshops, plus the mid-term, draft final, 
and final reports. Coordinate work of other experts. 
(ii)  Work with the team leader in supporting the ACMF to develop an implementation 
plan for an integrated capital market to achieve the AEC blueprint for 2015, which 
will encompass (a) greater harmonization of standards (offerings, disclosure, 
etc.), (b) mutual recognition of professional qualifications, (c) greater flexibility in 
language  and  legal  requirements  for  securities  markets,  (d)  enhanced 
withholding tax structure, (e) facilitation of market linkages (including exchange 
alliance as indicated by the AEC blueprint for 2015), and (f) a broader mutual 
recognition framework that includes collective investment schemes. 
(iii)  Work with the team leader in supporting a group of experts that will advise the 
ACMF in developing the implementation plan.  
(iv)  Work with the team leader in facilitating cooperation among stock exchanges and 
regulators in the region. 
(v)  Coordinate and participate, as needed, in the country visits by experts, plus 
oversee organization of workshops, meetings, and conferences. 
(vi)  Contribute to the conduct of IOSCO assessments, reviews, and analytical inputs 
for expert reports and findings. 
 
B.   National Consultants 
 
6.  Capital market expert (8 person-months) 
8.  The four national experts covering the ASEAN 5 countries will have backgrounds in 
capital markets, familiarity with the regulatory structure and operations of stock exchanges, and 
proficiency in English. National experts will assist the international consultants by (i) providing 
background information, (ii) helping develop databases on capital market development, and (iii) 
helping prepare and participating in conferences and workshops. Detailed terms of reference for 
national consultants will be prepared by the international consultants.  
 
7.  Project coordinator (2 person-months) 
9.  The project coordinator will have adequate experience in project management and will 
assist ADB, the team leader, and the other consultants. The consultant will perform the following 
tasks: 
(i)  Assist in designing and conducting the regional conference and seminars. 
(ii)  Assist in editing and consolidating the reports of the consultants. 
(iii)  Provide research and technical assistance to ADB, the team leader, and the 
other consultants in the preparation of reports. 
(iv)  Perform other tasks as reasonably requested by ADB.
